answers.text:
Hi, 
Thank you for reaching out on the Knowledge Network and asking this question. We get a lot of questions about breaking into local government at all different career stages and have many resources related to this. I would encourage you to do beyond the resources in this answer and search anything specific to your situation on the Knowledge Network which you can do by simply typing in the search field in the upper right hand corner. 
Fellowships and internships are a popular choice when breaking into local government. 
-This is a map that contains internship and fellowship programs that ICMA is either partners with or is aware of. There are likely other fellowships and internships out there but you may need to contact individual local governments to find them. http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/job_seekers/interns
-If you are willing to wait then you can apply to be an ICMA local government fellow for next year. The application opens in September 
2014. http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_development/lgmf_fellows/become_fellow
-you can also check out the Internship topic page from time to time to see when relevant information has been added or even ask questions specifically to the people interested in that topic. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/142/Internships
-Networking is always a good strategy especially when looking to break into a career at a higher level. On the Knowledge Network there is an area called Who's Who and you can use it to either search people in your geographic area to see if there are any job openings or what they really are looking for in applicants or you can search for people with the type of job description you are hoping to have and see if they have any advice. They might be able to give you tips on how to break the cycle of city manager-assistant city manager that you talk about in your question. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/people/whos_who
-Finally here is a check list for your first 5 years in local government that can help you define your local government and job goals. http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_resources/news_reports_presentations/first_five_years
I hope you find these resources helpful and feel free to post another question in the future if you are looking for more in depth or other advice. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern

author: [Anonymous]
text:
What is the best way to get started in the local government career?  As someone who was employed at a police department for 18 years, I decided to go back and get a law degree, which I did.  I already have a Master's in Public Administration and did a summer internship at the City Manager's office for the city was employed in before going back to school.  Now I want to get into city administration and as such, what is the best way to be a city manager?  Is it to start in human resources, business services, public relations?  It seems the assistant city manager jobs advertised all want experience as a city manager.  It seems to be circular; be an assistant city manager first to get experience but do not apply to be an assistant if you do not have experience.  
Suggestions are welcome.
title: Ideas on the best way to get started in local government career
